author: {'steamid': '76561198201209477', 'num_games_owned': 1947, 'num_reviews': 152, 'playtime_forever': 104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1710179115}

author: {'steamid': '76561198015171654', 'num_games_owned': 1083, 'num_reviews': 308, 'playtime_forever': 122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 122, 'last_played': 1699264822}
review: Holy shit was this a cool title to go through! It has no saving but can be pretty short to play through. I'm not all that great at platformers but this retro one with a twist was ok enough for me to get through and beat. If you happen to have a game over, you start on the level you died on which I think is pretty neat. Another pretty neat thing is the story. The way it was presented especially in the levels that you play and how that correlates with the protagonist was phenomenal. The writing was lackluster and I think more time could have gone into better dialogue but the overall concept made up for that for me. But yeah! A solid game! It gets a rec!

author: {'steamid': '76561199069553145', 'num_games_owned': 1326, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1698286791}
review:
This game is very good.

Gorgeous pixel art, satisfying gameplay and can be finished in a short amount of time. Even the story is very interesting for what it is. Also, a lot of variety in the gameplay, there's always a surprise as you progress through the game.

On my first playthrough I almost game over at several points, but since the difficulty is a rollercoaster I've been always able to make a comeback. But the second one was basically a speedrun, and ended up with 50 lives on average, so the learning experience of the first run was very rewarding.

The only flaws are the difficulty balance and the boss fights. Some of the early stages can feel very challenging on a first playthrough, while the later worlds can be the complete opposite. Bosses are a joke, which is sad considering that some have completely unique gameplay systems.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094432643', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106, 'last_played': 1667714276}
review: I guess I'll leave a review because it's a cute game? Although to be honest, it takes a bit of adjustment to get the hang of the controls. I had so many problems JUST in the first screen since I couldn't figure out what to do. The game feels harder than the average platformer since almost every jump requires double-jump and so many enemies require multiple hits to kill. By this metric, it's also a very LONG game as, even though you get a LOT of lives to start with, and an extra life every 600 points (and, seems like, INFINITE continues), EVERYTHING is one-hit kill, so unless you have mastered the controls and enemy timing, etc., you'll be replaying stages until you get tired (and also there's no password or level select that I know of, so you have to do it in one sitting). Luckily, it has controller support, so if you can't manage with keyboard controls (I couldn't), that's a happier option.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100764535', 'num_games_owned': 291, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 236, 'last_played': 1611439989}

author: {'steamid': '76561197989078937', 'num_games_owned': 2467, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 422, 'last_played': 1590098740}
review: A short and bittersweet story made this a somewhat rewarding game to complete. The platforming gameplay features wonky controls, strange level design, strange bosses, strange challenges. It's very unpolished but also similar to old Master System games, which I enjoyed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012778917', 'num_games_owned': 2877, 'num_reviews': 165, 'playtime_forever': 104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1509766569}
review:
Well, I don't think this game is bad. Sometimes it can be the kind of unfair-like game where you need to step into something to know that it is a problem, but usually it tells you to be aware of the problems happening. 
Also, it is pretty forgiving in the fact that it gives you a lot of lives.
Yeah, sometimes I thought this game was a little bit unfair but sometimes I thought it was too forgiving
Either way, it doesn't tell you the qualities of the game

It is a simple platformer, you jump, you cut things and you throw knives. A single hit and you're dead, while some enemies take some hits to die and you need to be careful. 
The graphics are pretty cute, which makes the game worth by itself.
It is also pretty short, which I think is good, because, for me, it does not need to me much more than this.

Overall, a pretty ok game, I don't think the price is unfair at all and you can have some nice little fun with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027267313', 'num_games_owned': 1838, 'num_reviews': 4460, 'playtime_forever': 218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1507687024}
review:
Tags: Platformer
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: Broken. Reinstalling fresh did not help. Stuck at menu. Pressing inputs on KB or Xboxpad plays sounds but no other results. Process must be force closed on exit. 

Win1064bit Ryzen+Polaris. 

Typical indie 8bit inspired platformer. I thought for sure I had tried this game not so long ago and it was working... Felt like Bloo Kid or 8bit boy. But featuring a cat protag that would do roll jumping arcs like a ninja that were actually a bit slow and akward. Otherwise there was not much to complain about. Saw reviewers claiming this only had less than two hours of content so I decided I would try beating it and writing a definitive review on it but could not get past the menu. 

Rather annoyingly, this game has a phantom process that remains open after quitting. I really looked keenly at the processes tab and could not readily identify what was going on. Removing for declutter.
developer_response:
Sorry for the late reply.
Thank you for reporting about the phantom process and getting stuck.
The game has been rewritten from scratch, so hopefully both issues are fixed in the new build.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112578624', 'num_games_owned': 626, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1502316000}
review:
You can beat this game in about 90 minutes with little difficulty (most of my recorded play time was spent just leaving the game idle to get trading cards), and once you do there is no compelling reason to come back to it. There's no achievements, no hard mode, no unlockables, there's really nothing that adds any sort of replay value outside of playing the game again to beat your high score. 

This is also the first game I've ever encountered that runs in super slow-motion with G-Sync enabled.  This is fixed by setting the game to run at fixed refresh in the graphics control panel, but then of course G-Sync is disabled, which is lame.

If you *really* want to give this game a try then wait until it gets a steep discount, otherwise it just ain't worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971735129', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 79, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1709754823}
review:
I have to start saying that this game concept is really good. Simple platformer with stunning graphics.

Controls are not too hard, and the levels tend to be short giving a great feeling of accomplishment.

But there is unfortunately a downside, and its a big downside. This game would receive a big thumbs up if it weren't for this flaw.

The game does not save any progress, so if you quit the game, you have to start over. Its not a hard game, but it does mean you need to have time. This is not a "I'll play a world and continue tomorrow" kind of game. You will effectively need to keep the game running in the background and put your computer to sleep if you want to finish the game.

The developers mentioned this was intentional and that it takes about 4 to 5 hours to play the entire game if you know it inside out. Well, I am not that good and reaching world 3 took me a bit more than 3 hours.

Until the developers add a "world selection screen" or a "password" mode I will not recommend this game to anyone. Too bad really, because this is a game with lots of potential.
developer_response:
Thank you for taking the time to write a review and sorry for the late reply.

The save system has been fixed in the newest build. The world selection screen will be added in the next update.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025540438', 'num_games_owned': 7104, 'num_reviews': 559, 'playtime_forever': 297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 231, 'last_played': 1479879266}
review:
A fun old-style platformer with wonderful visuals and soundtrack that really capture the dreamlike feel the dev was going for.

Overall the difficulty hits the sweet spot of not being too easy or too hard. There's a short minecart section you're pretty much guaranteed to lose quite a few lives on, but beyond that there's nothing rage-incuding.

While the dialogue is a bit rough (at one point they spell crisis "crysis", like the video game), the actual story being told is pretty cool and well worth not letting some grammar and sentence flow errors ruin it for you.

If you didn't see on the store page, be aware that the game has no save function. It takes just shy of two hours to beat, so make sure you set the time aside to clear it in one go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043788830', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1467449343}
review: It tries to be one of those odd Taito / Data East arcade games like "Trio the Punch" or "Pu-Li-Ru-La", but falls flat considerably in presentation. There is no real outright "story". The level design is pure garbage. You start at least the first 3 levels of the second world right next to spikes, so that when you walk left even 1 pixel, you die. It also takes 2 minutes to load...as a 2D game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11207, 'playtime_forever': 422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 418, 'last_played': 1512897061}
review:
There's right ways and wrong ways to release a 2D platformer on Steam.

The right way is to combine great gameplay with real artwork and a contemporary instead of pitching a low effort deal and not reverting to the old and dead "retro" look to avoid having to hire an artist. 

The developers of SWR JST DX Selective Memory Erase Effect decided on the latter.

Gameplay - Terrible platformer with a clunky engine

Artwork - None - they opted for a slightly japanese looking 8 bit motif - it's old, tired, done, and dead but here they are rehashing it again as if it's somehow still cool and hipster to be retro.  It's not.

Engine - Some special comments on the game engine.  They decided to use an arcade emu for the game without permitting widescreen or even 4:3 graphics - so if you own a PC, this game will look terrible on it, and not just because of the terrible 8bit style.   You cannot change the engine and the controls aren't by default mapped to a keyboard or joystick, it expects a gamepad, which would be great if this was a console game but it's not. 

A whole series of things are wrong with this entry into the overcrowded cesspit of "me too" retro platformers.   I'd have a hard time recommending a good entry, and this most certainly isn't one.  Avoid.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063207722', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 142, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 142, 'last_played': 1464906837}
review:
Un peque√±o juego que te har√° recordar la √©poca dorada de la nes y las arcades con su simpleza y gr√°ficos pixelados coronados por un filtro retro.
El objetivo del juego en "SWR JST DX Selective Memory Erase Effect"  (Best Name Ever...) es conducir a un peque√±o gato ninja a travez de los cortos pero duros niveles de plataformas llenos de bizarros enemigos, con el fin de llegar a reiniciar la memoria de una chica de quien somos su mu√±eco mascota... suena raro, lo se, pero el juego va de eso.
Los gr√°ficos son extra√±os pero atractivos y el dise√±o de cada pantalla es interesante pero muy breve.
La jugbilidad me hizo recordar (por alguna extra√±a raz√≥n) a Tiger Road de Capcom, tal vez por su imprecisi√≥n o por lo tosco de los movimientos, aunque una vez cruzada la linea de frustraci√≥n nos adaptaremos a ellos y no ser√°n ning√∫n inconveniente.
El apartado sonoro no es nada destacable, pero acompa√±a y no molesta.
Lo que me gustaria defender es el punto que varios han marcado de negativo, que es la falta de guardado...
Vamos, es un juego que lo termin√°s en 2 hs, ¬ørealmente es tan necesario que tenga opci√≥n de guardado?
Es un juego para terminar de un tir√≥n, no para hacer partecita por partecita. ¬°Que son 2 hs solamente, no es Skyrim!
En definitiva √©ste es un buen juego, compacto divertido y con un historia intrigante (y muy bizarra).
Lo recomiendo para fan√°ticos de la vieja escuela y gente que no se frustre con facilidad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070053006', 'num_games_owned': 673, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1463908991}
review:
[h1] Overview	[/h1]

Adopting a retro arcade 8-bit art style, the SWR JST DX Selective Memory Erase Effect, or Sword Justice Deluxe Selective Memory Erase Effect plays as a 2D platformer where you move your character, a mechanical android cat through different layers of fear clusters in order to reach an end terminal to log out and return to the real world where his link partner, M1Mi resides in.  Along the way, the cat meets many parts of the operating system that take a physical form as enemies.  In order to progress through the game, players must complete each level by moving their character from the left to the right; killing enemies along the way which will increase your score.  The developer has taken an extra step, whether intentional or not to bring the complete experience of a CRT arcade cabinet by featuring in-game screen brightness control for CRTs‚Äô, three button layouts found on cabinets and of course, infinite continues.

[h1] The Good	[/h1]

SWR JST DX Selective Memory Erase Effect follows true to the standard cabinet platformer.  To give an idea of how the game is like, think of the original metal slug, except your default weapon is a blade instead of a pistol.  Jumping, ducking, dodging, button mashing all the good mechanical components of cabinet games are retained in SWR JST DX SMEE and mesh really well to play a fun to play game.

SWR JST DX Selective Memory Erase Effect‚Äôs visuals are extremely well done.  For a game with only 256 different shades of colours to work with, this game manages to bring colourful visuals with unique background design for every chapter.  Although enemy mechanics and attack patterns were used in more than one type of enemy, each chapter of the game introduced new and special looking sprites for all the enemies.  

The difficulty of the game increases at a reasonable rate.  The first few chapters introduce players to the mechanics, and slowly become more demanding, such as throwing daggers while dodging and immediately air strafing in the opposite direction to slash an incoming enemy.  

The plot is based off of a good concept which actually revolves around an inner conflict that appears within the player. Taking a step back, you can see there are two sides of the story.  One of which is really evident to the player, the cat‚Äôs drive to log out of this nightmare and return to M1Mi.  But in order to reach the terminal, all the operating system enemies‚Äô have everything that they longed for destroyed.  Looking back into the dialogue between the main characters, reveals that the main antagonist isn‚Äôt even truly evil, but just someone whose ideals sided with the OS components. 

[h1] The Bad [/h1]

Let‚Äôs start with the game itself.  Mentioned earlier, I‚Äôm not sure whether or not the developer decided to bring about the whole experience of old arcade games including the problems, or was just simply limited by the game engine they are working with.  Please note, at the time of writing this review, the game cannot save, meaning each time you start the game up, you have to start from the very beginning.  The argument may be that the game is short and can be completed in one sitting, but it is just a poor excuse that a save function not be implemented, if high scores can be recorded.  SWR JST DX SMEE also has problems shutting down properly.  The window may close, but it hangs on steam locking you in-game.  In order to play your other games again you have to shut down steam and restart the client.
 
Level design is not the best, and is very evident in the ice chapter where you utilize the same run and gun strategy.  Progression between levels can be spontaneous and abrupt with no warning narrative as seen by the mine cart stage. The result is a lot of gimmicky level designs that force you to lose a life no matter what, unless you‚Äôve played through a second time.

The game itself is contradictory as to the scoring style.  2D side-scrolling platformer games like these usually are fast paced because they provide you with a ranged default weapon and unlimited ammunition.  Since SWR JST DX Selective Memory Erase Effect gives you a sword as a default weapon, you will often find yourself kiting backwards and staying just outside of the enemy hit range.  Anyone who has played a 2D side-scroller knows that going back the way you came from breaks the tempo of the game and since scoring is widely based off of number of enemies killed, you are forced to kill your enemies, making pacifist and speed runs totally redundant, not to mention impossible on some of the later levels. 

The plot itself is pretty shallow and leaves a lot to be desired.  Yes, the writer may have been going for a hero vs villain scenario, but nine lines of text between levels is not enough for the player to connect with the characters, leaving an empty and hollow characters.  It really is not enough for the player to judge the scenario correctly, and is hard to sympathize for the other cast of characters that are being antagonized. 

[h1] Overall Score [/h1]

As a complete package I rate Sword Justice Deluxe Selective Memory Erase Effect at 4/10.  This game is just too large of a hassle to get up and running and an even bigger annoyance when it comes to shutting down.   If you look at just the game, I would personally score this game at 6/10 just for the amazing visuals and good controls.  The reason it isn‚Äôt higher is because the game really falls short in terms of level design.  But if the game‚Äôs art piques your interest and your computer successfully passes the [url=https://nekomuragames.itch.io/swr-jst-dx-selective-memory-erase-effect] tech demo [/url], give this game a try.
developer_response:
Hi, thank you and sorry for the late reply.

"at the time of writing this review, the game cannot save, meaning each time you start the game up, you have to start from the very beginning."
Saving has been added in the new update.

"problems shutting down properly. The window may close, but it hangs on steam locking you in-game. In order to play your other games again you have to shut down steam and restart the client."
The newest build is meant to behave correctly and shut down properly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026123571', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 677, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 313, 'last_played': 1709881951}
review:
An amusing though melancholic short story about dreams and consciousness presented as a platformer whose levels are little positioning\timing puzzles. Not stingy on lives and checkpoints so practically anyone can finish it, but if you want to challenge yourself you can shoot for a high-score.

Pleasing to both the visual and the aural receptors. Admirably atmospheric.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968407942', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 569, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1710851581}
review:
Just going by the screenshots, SWR JST DX Selective Memory Erase Effect may seem like a fairly unimpressive and milquetoast retro throwback, but in all actuality it's a solid little platformer with a cyberspace-tinged storyline that really goes places and enough variety and charm to make it well worth recommending.  

Firstly, this game looks wonderful in action. Screenshots really don't do the lush backgrounds and fantastic digitized-looking sprite work justice.  The interstitial animations also look great, and there's a fairly memorable soundtrack backing everything.  This is a game that does not drop the ball at all with its presentation. 

Gameplay-wise, it's about as arcadey an experience as you can get. As a cute little robot ninja cat, you'll run, jump, slash, and throw daggers to overcome most of your obstacles, but the game's strength is the staggering amount of variety it manages to pack into all of its stages.  Nearly every world has a unique set of gimmicks and challenges to overcome and it's always shuffling you in and out of new situations so you never end up doing too much of the same thing for long.  

Each level is a fairly bite-sized affair, lasting roughly 30 seconds, and nearly all of them are fairly challenging (except the bosses. They're all chumps), but there's nothing that can't be overcome with a little persistence.  There are however a couple gimmicks that feel like they needed a bit more work.  The stages that drop your character into a boat with only a sword and some daggers to defend yourself don't feel properly balanced at all, and this is only emphasized later in the same world when you're able to equip your boat with a proper projectile weapon.  The mine cart stage a bit later in the game, though fairly short, is a nightmare of randomly generated nonsense that can create many impossible situations and was really a low point for me. 

Other than those niggling flaws, I had a blast with the game.  It'll take you just over a couple hours to see it to completion, and even though the overly easy boss encounters kind of make for an anti-climax, the storyline and stages leading up to them are definitely solid enough to stand on their own.

author: {'steamid': '76561198090468054', 'num_games_owned': 3608, 'num_reviews': 130, 'playtime_forever': 258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 258, 'last_played': 1447852531}
review: SWR JST DX Selective Memory Erase Effect √® un gioco che neanche avevo idea di possedere in libreria, ma che si √® rivelato una piccola gemma inaspettata che ha toccato le giuste corde della mia sensibilit√†. Una piccola avvertenza sulla sua particolare natura va fatta: il titolo in questione prende a ispirazione i vecchi platform in formato cabinato da sala giochi, ed √® quindi pensato esplicitamente per essere iniziato e finito in una sola run di circa un paio d'ore (con "continua" infiniti). Il titolo non stanca mai con una discreta variet√† di situazioni, livelli brevi e frequentemente (e sapientemente) intervallati dall'incalzare dialogico della trama. Sebbene sia dunque quest'ultima il motore trainante di tutta la genuinit√† di questa produzione, il comparto grafico risulta veramente di buon livello (gli screenshot dello store non rendono giustizia), ingraziosito da pixel art statiche (ma molto drammatiche!) per i momenti pi√π solenni come la sconfitta dei boss. E ora via con i contenuti: "L'effetto della cancellazione selettiva della memoria" tratta sotto una maschera di tenero sci-fi (che non pu√≤ non ricordare lo spielberghiano A.I. Artificial Intelligence) un tema molto delicato, e lo fa con estremo tatto e contemporaneamente con incisivit√†. A volte alcuni cari con cui avevamo particolarmente legato, con cui addirittura ci sentivamo in un rapporto di mutua interdipendenza, ci lasciano dopo un avvenimento drammatico soli, o meglio: gli ultimi ricordi della persona cara arrivano a monopolizzare la nostra esistenza, e sono ricordi di paura, addirittura panico. Un panico cos√¨ acuto da rimettere in discussione la capacit√† di sopportazione pi√π basilare, lasciandoci in un tunnel paralizzante di "blocchi" psicologici. E qui arriva l'idea grandiosa della simulazione della personalit√† altrui: cosa avrebbe fatto la persona cara davanti alla nostra perdita, ovvero la perdita... di se stessa? Le opzioni sono due: o lasciarsi andare alla pazzia, in cui ogni nostra funzione cognitiva si slega dall'insieme in una farsa che si regge a stento nella sua dimensione utopistica, consapevole dell'effimerit√† di questo stato; oppure andare a sbattere contro tutti i blocchi, e contro il nostro stesso spirito di autoconservazione, verso una destinazione ignota in cui la persona persa che vive dentro di noi e il noi dolente della stessa perdita andranno definitivamente persi. A che pro? La normalit√†. Anche se nell'immediato pu√≤ sembrare un enorme salto nel vuoto, il gioco punta a favore di una visione in cui questa √® il pi√π grande pegno di amicizia verso il caro che non c'√® pi√π, che ha bisogno di essere lasciato andare. Il gioco tratta cos√¨ di due tipi di perdite di memorie: la prima, quella che rende l'inconsapevole coraggioso e il consapevole codardo. La seconda, ancora pi√π positiva in tutto il pieno significato agentivo di "selettiva", consiste nell'accantonare nella quotidianit√† le paure elementari, relegandole a quello che sono: segnali di allarme esclusivamente contestuali, e non permanenti. SWR JST DX Selective Memory Erase Effect √® tutto questo, e la vostra memoria di certo non vi far√† lo scherzo di dimenticarlo in fretta.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045048814', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 108, 'last_played': 1447051219}
review:
I picked this up from a bundle and it's definitely a neat 2 hour adventure.

Aesthetics and music are definitely the highlights of this game. The backgrounds/atmospheres are not bland. The platforming is solid, never had a problem with it. Some of the enemies are put in unfair places, but the game is generous with lives/continues.

My only main gripe is the minecart section. I spent an entire continue on it because the first obstacle was a jump...and there was always a boulder right above me. Incredibly frustrating because it just became luck at that point, hoping I didn't have to jump when there was a boulder coming down.

Also, you have to play this game in 1 sitting. There is no save feature except for scores at the very end.

Overall it was a pretty nice experience, but I don't expect to play it ever again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993279741', 'num_games_owned': 2713, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 98, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 98, 'last_played': 1446859920}
review:
Aesthetics-wise, there's nifty pixel art with some effects reminiscent of those found in Dynamite Headdy or Mischief Makers, and the music is pleasant.  Play-wise, expect something of a cross between I Wanna Be the Guy and Dark Souls - one hit will kill you, and some enemy placements are designed to surprise in a seemingly unfair way, but if you go slow and take the time to analyze level patterns, success won't be so far off.  With that said, the player starts with plenty of lives, and there's infinite continues for those who don't care much for high-scores.  The minecart section is a jerk, though, especially the tail-end.

The game can be played through in an afternoon or less, which is fine, but there's no saving level progress, only score.  Another potential issue is that the game can hang after closing, leaving one's Steam status reading as in-game long after one has stopped.  It might be an issue with the Steam overlay, so a solution could be disabling that, maybe?  I haven't tried it, but since these issues aren't too terrible, I'm still satisfied with this purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012343425', 'num_games_owned': 2567, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1457730328}
review: This game doesn't close properly - Steam continues to think it's running even when there's no trace of the exe. If this bothers you, avoid.
developer_response:
In some cases closing of the game does not get registered immediately (takes some time to clean up after itself).

For example when starting the game from the Steam client, closing the game and trying to start it immediately afterwards will result in Steam client showing a warning that the game is still running and can't be run again - but just give it a bit of time and the game can be run normally.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981047937', 'num_games_owned': 7466, 'num_reviews': 437, 'playtime_forever': 250, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 250, 'last_played': 1435952470}
review:
It's an 80s-esque arcade platformer, just shy of being a MAME title or something. It even has the menu set up as an operator menu. It's pretty solid, my only gripe is that some of the platforms can be a little deceptive about where they end (turning your double jump into a single jump to your death...), otherwise though, it's a game you can play through in an afternoon. And you have to, as it has no save feature, only the ability to infinitely credit-feed. That said, it's forgiving enough. Any levels longer than a few screens seem to silently checkpoint themselves, there's no timer, and powerups are relatively frequent. The game changes tactics from world to world as well, so it doesn't run the risk of repetition.

I dig it. Well worth a pickup.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965248924', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1429576435}
review:
On my system this game is subject to a very strange bug: SWR runs at half speed unless I have a dinput device plugged in like my PS360+ based stick or 3D Extreme Pro flight stick. SWR doesn't recognize the directional input on the former and the latter is wildly unsuited to platformers. So I have to plug in a controller and then use my keyboard. Weird, lazy stuff Nekomura Games.

Having said that it's a perfectly serviceable indie platformer, well worth the five bucks even with the gamble that you'll run into the same bug that I did.
